questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign to elicit appendicitis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above Options: A, B & C. All of the above are signs present in patients with appendicitis. Clinical examination of the abdomen in appendicitis: The cardinal features are those of an unwell patient with low-grade pyrexia, localised abdominal tenderness, muscle guarding, and rebound tenderness. Inspection of the abdomen may show limitation of respiratory movement in the lower abdomen. Pointing sign: The patient is then asked to point to where the pain began and where it moved. Gentle superficial palpation of the abdomen, beginning in the left iliac fossa and moving anticlockwise to the right iliac fossa, will detect muscle guarding over the point of maximum tenderness, classically McBurney’s point . Asking the patient to cough or gentle percussion over the site of maximum tenderness will elicit rebound tenderness. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa may cause pain in the right iliac fossa, Rovsing’s sign , which helps support a clinical diagnosis of appendicitis. The Psoas occasionally sign an inflamed appendix that lies on the Psoas muscle, and the patient, often a young adult, will lie with the right hip flexed for pain relief. Obturator sign : Spasm of the obturator internus is sometimes demonstrable when the hip is flexed and internally rotated. If an inflamed appendix is in contact with the obturator internus, this manoeuvre will cause pain in the hypogastrium. Cutaneous hyperesthesia may be demonstrable in the right iliac fossa but is rarely of diagnostic value.

Highyeild:

Table -1- Important signs of appendicitis: table,tr,th,td {border:1px solid black;} ROVSING SIGN PRESSURE ON THE LEFT ILIAC FOSSA CAUSES PAIN IN THE RIGHT ILIAC FOSSA PSOAS SIGN HYPEREXTENSION OF THE RIGHT HIP OR FLEXION OF THE RIGHT HIP AGAINST RESISTANCE CAUSES PAIN OBTURATOR SIGN FLEXION AND INTERNAL ROTATION OF THE RIGHT HIP CAUSE PAIN

Extraedge:

table,tr,th,td {border:1px solid black;} SIGN CHARACTERISTIC PRESENT IN: TEN HORN SIGN PAIN ON GENTLE TRACTION OF RIGHT TESTICLE. APPENDICITIS BLUMBERG’S SIGN TRANSIENT ABDOMINAL WALL REBOUND TENDERNESS PERITONEAL INFLAMMATION BASSELER SIGN SHARP PAIN CREATED BY COMPRESSION OF APPENDIX BETWEEN ILIACUS AND ABDOMINAL WALL CHRONIC APPENDICITIS AARON SIGN PAIN OR PRESSURE IN EPIGASTRIUM OR ANTERIOR CHEST WITH PERSISTENT PRESSURE AT Mc BURNEY’S POINT ACUTE APPENDICITIS DUNPHY SIGN PAIN ON COUGHING ACUTE APPENDICITIS

questions.text: The following carries 2 points in Alvarado's score:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tenderness(RIF) Alvarado (MANTRELS) score: Symptoms: Migratory RIF pain -1 Anorexia -1 Nausea and vomiting -1 SIGNS: Tenderness (RIF)-2 Rebound tenderness-1 Elevated temperature- 1 LABORATORY: Leucocytosis- 2 Shift to left- 1 Total- 10

Highyeild:

To aid in the diagnosis of acute appendicitis the Alvarado score being the most commonly used. A score of 7 or higher is highly indicative of acute appendicitis. In cases where the score is equivocal (5 or 6), abdominal ultrasonography or contrast-enhanced CT examination can help reduce the rate of negative appendectomies.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. C & D. Migratory RIF pain Rebound tenderness Elevated temperature carries 1 point in Alvarado score.

Extraedge:

CT scanning is a valuable diagnostic tool, particularly in cases where the clinical suspicion of acute appendicitis is equivocal, as indicated by an Alvarado score of 5 or 6. CT scans have a high sensitivity of 90% and a specificity of 80-90% for detecting acute appendicitis in patients with abdominal pain. Classic CT findings include a distended appendix with a diameter greater than 7 mm, circumferential wall thickening and enhancement, and the presence of an appendicolith. CT scans can help reduce the rate of negative appendectomies and improve diagnostic accuracy.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting for 12 hours. Her abdominal pain was initially dull and diffuse but has progressed to a sharp pain on the lower right side. Two years ago, she had to undergo right salpingo-oophorectomy after an ectopic pregnancy. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F). Physical examination shows severe right lower quadrant tenderness with rebound tenderness; bowel sounds are decreased. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis with left shift. An abdominal CT scan shows a distended, edematous appendix. The patient is taken to the operating room for an appendectomy. During the surgery, the adhesions from the patient's previous surgery make it difficult for the resident surgeon to identify the appendix. Her consultant surgeon mentions that she should use a certain structure for guidance to locate the appendix. The surgeon is most likely referring to which of the following structures?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Taenia coli The Taenia coli , three longitudinal smooth muscle bands on the surface of the cecum and colon, converge where the appendix arises from the cecum. Therefore, the taenia coli can be used as guidance to locate the appendix during surgery.

Highyeild:

Appendix, ileum, and ascending colon originate from the midgut The appendiceal artery, a branch of the ileocolic artery supplies the appendix The length of the appendix ranges from 2 to 20 cm with an average length of 9 cm in adults The base of the appendix is situated at the point where the taeniae meet on the inferior side of the cecum Retrocecal is the most common location for the appendix, while post-ileal is the least common.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia lateral to the epigastric vessels. The right deep inguinal ring is located in the right lower quadrant. However, this structure is part of the abdominal wall and too superficial to be used as guidance for locating the appendix during surgery. Option: C. The ileocolic artery arises from the superior mesenteric artery and supplies the distal ileum, cecum, appendix, and proximal ascending colon. This artery or its branches (e.g., appendicular artery) must be ligated during an appendectomy. However, the ileocolic artery is not specific enough to locate the appendix during surgery. Option: D. The right ureter is a retroperitoneal organ that lies near the appendix in the right lower quadrant and, therefore, needs to be identified during appendectomy to prevent iatrogenic injury. However, because the appendix is located intraperitoneally, the right ureter cannot be used for guidance during an appendectomy.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman visits the physician for right lower abdominal pain for 6 months. She has multiple non-bloody, watery bowel movements daily and experiences abdominal cramping. Sometimes, she feels sudden palpitations, is short of breath, and her face becomes red. She has lost 7 kg over the past 3 months. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. Her temperature is 37˚C (98.6°F), her pulse is 72/min, and her blood pressure is 126/70 mm Hg. On physical examination, tiny blood vessels are noted on her face and arms. Lung auscultation shows bilateral wheezing. The abdomen is soft and nondistended. There is localised tenderness to the right lower quadrant but no rebound tenderness or guarding. Laboratory studies show: Leukocyte count 4,600/mm3 Haemoglobin 13.1 g/dL Serum Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 110 IU/L Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 128 IU/L C-reactive protein 8 mg/dL (N= 0-10) Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carcinoid tumor This patient most likely has a carcinoid tumor, as indicated by typical features of carcinoid syndrome, including abdominal tenderness and cramps, watery diarrhea, cutaneous flushing (facial redness), telangiectasia (tiny blood vessels), tachycardia (sudden palpitations), and wheezing. Carcinoid tumors usually occur in the GI tract and are often asymptomatic due to the hepatic metabolism of neuroendocrine substances (particularly serotonin) that the tumors produce. Appendix is the most common site of carcinoid tumour. In the case of extraintestinal carcinoid tumors and tumors that have metastasised to the liver (indicated by elevation of transaminases in this patient), the increased serotonin bypasses hepatic first-pass metabolism and enters systemic circulation causes the symptoms.

Highyeild:

Appearance: Firm, yellow, bulbar mass in the appendix. Majority of carcinoids are located in the tip of the appendix. Mean tumor size is 2.5 cm for carcinoids. 64% of carcinoid tumors present with localised disease. Carcinoid syndrome is rare in appendiceal carcinoid, unless widespread metastases are present. Symptoms directly attributable to the carcinoid are rare, but the tumor can cause appendiceal obstruction and acute appendicitis. Malignant potential is related to size, with tumors < 1 cm rarely extending outside the appendix or adjacent to the mass.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Chronic watery diarrhea, as in this patient, is the main symptom of VIPomas (tumors that secrete vasoactive intestinal polypeptide, VIP), besides dehydration, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. Although cutaneous flushing can occasionally occur in individuals with a VIPoma, this diagnosis would not explain this patient's telangiectasia and wheezing. Option: B. Chronic appendicitis typically presents with RLQ pain persisting for over three weeks. The diagnosis is usually made by postoperative relief of symptoms and histopathological confirmation of appendicitis. Chronic appendicitis can present with abdominal tenderness and normal markers of inflammation (CRP, leukocyte count), as seen here. However, it is not associated with cutaneous flushing, telangiectasia, or pulmonary symptoms, making another diagnosis more likely. Option: C. Ascaris lumbricoides infection can cause pulmonary symptoms, such as wheezing and shortness of breath (larvae migrate to the lungs), as well as abdominal symptoms, including abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, and features of appendicitis (RLQ complaints due to obstruction of the appendix by adult worms), as seen in this patient. Furthermore, this patient is at increased risk for ascariasis, as she spent time in Cambodia, which is endemic for Ascaris lumbricoides. However, this type of infection would typically cause eosinophilia and is normally not associated with cutaneous flushing and telangiectasia.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a history of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and decreased appetite for 2 days. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F). Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation with guarding in the right lower quadrant. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 12,800/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lymphatic tissue hyperplasia This patient most likely presents with acute appendicitis. Lymphatic tissue hyperplasia is the primary etiology of appendicitis in children; fecolith obstruction is the most common etiology in adults. Obstruction within the appendix results in mucus and fluids stasis, allowing bacterial overgrowth and ultimately causing organ inflammation. Patients with appendicitis typically present with abdominal pain (dull migratory periumbilical pain that progresses to sharp right lower quadrant pain), fever, loss of appetite, nausea, and leukocytosis, as seen in this patient.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Bacterial mesenteric lymphadenitis is the underlying etiology of pseudoappendicitis. The disease manifests with right lower quadrant pain, fever, vomiting, and leukocytosis, identical to the findings observed in this patient. However, pseudoappendicitis primarily affects children under 5 years of age. Option: B. Pseudomembranous plaque formation in the colon is a distinctive feature of Clostridium difficile colitis. The disease manifests with diarrhea, fever, abdominal pain, and leukocytosis, similar to the symptoms seen in this patient. However, C. difficile colitis is predominantly antibiotic-associated diarrhea, and this patient has no history of antibiotic intake. Moreover, Clostridium difficile colitis primarily occurs in patients older than 65 years (often after recent hospitalisation) and would be unlikely in this 15-year-old patient. Option: C. Diverticular inflammation (diverticulitis) can manifest with low-grade fevers, loss of appetite, diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain (typically left lower quadrant pain). However, diverticulitis primarily occurs in patients older than 60 and would be unlikely in this 15-year-old patient.

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravida woman, at 30 weeks gestation, is brought to the emergency department because of progressive upper abdominal pain for the past hour. The patient vomited once on her way to the hospital. She states that she initially had dull stomach pain about 6 hours ago, but now the pain is located in the upper abdomen and is more severe. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 38.5°C, her pulse is 100/min, and her blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows right upper quadrant tenderness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 12,000/mm3. Urinalysis shows mild pyuria. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Appendicitis Dull pain that gradually worsens and eventually localises to the right abdomen is characteristic of appendicitis. This is the most common cause of acute abdomen in pregnancy. Although appendicitis pain classically localizes to the right lower quadrant (McBurney point), in pregnant patients, the gravid uterus can displace the appendix towards the right upper quadrant. Sterile pyuria is a common finding in appendicitis and can occur if part of the urinary tract (usually the ureters) is within proximity of the inflamed appendix.

Highyeild:

Acute appendicitis is commonly caused by obstruction of the lumen. Obstruction can result from various factors, such as the presence of inspissated stool, lymphoid hyperplasia, or a vegetable matter plug. Obstruction causes an increase in pressure within the appendix, leading to inflammation, infection, and, ultimately acute appendicitis. Other factors like infections, trauma, or tumors may also contribute to the development of appendicitis. Pain typically localises to the right lower quadrant as the inflammatory process progresses and involves the parietal peritoneum overlying the appendix. Localized pain in the right lower quadrant is a classic pattern of migratory pain and is the most reliable symptom of acute appendicitis. Other symptoms may include vomiting, fever, and leukocytosis. In some cases, patients may also experience urinary symptoms or microscopic hematuria.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Urinary tract infections classically present with dysuria, urinary frequency/urgency, and suprapubic pain. Although this patient presents with pyuria on urinalysis, the lack of clinical symptoms of urinary tract infection makes asymptomatic bacteriuria a better explanation for her urinalysis results. Urinary tract infection would not present with upper abdominal pain or right upper quadrant tenderness. Option: B. The risk of ovarian torsion increases in pregnancy due to ovarian enlargement. Although it also presents with vomiting, fever, and leukocytosis (as seen in this patient), ovarian torsion would not present with RUQ tenderness. Instead, it presents with lower abdominal and pelvic pain. Option: C. HELLP syndrome is a life-threatening complication of pregnancy that, if present, requires immediate delivery. Although HELLP syndrome can present with vomiting, abdominal pain, and RUQ tenderness (as seen in this patient), it also classically presents with hypertension and proteinuria. In addition, the laboratory findings that give HELLP syndrome its name are not present in this case: signs of hemolysis (H), elevated liver enzymes (EL) and low platelets (LP). The absence of these associated findings makes HELLP syndrome unlikely.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presents with signs and symptoms of acute appendicitis. She is taken to the operating room, and a standard appendectomy is performed, although there is a studding of her peritoneum with white plaques throughout the abdomen. The frozen section of the peritoneal plaques confirms mucinous adenocarcinoma. The procedure is completed, and the final Pathology from the appendix confirms a low-grade mucinous adenocarcinoma with positive margins. A Staging CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis is performed. Tumor markers and colonoscopy are normal. What is the next step in her management?

options.label: B
options.text: Exploratory laparotomy, right hemicolectomy, complete cytoreduction, and intraperitoneal chemotherapy

questions.correct_answer: B. Exploratory laparotomy, right hemicolectomy, complete cytoreduction, and intraperitoneal chemotherapy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Exploratory laparotomy, right hemicolectomy, complete cytoreduction, and intraperitoneal chemotherapy Diagnosis of Adenocarcinoma: Imaging and HPE: Treatment of adenocarcinoma of the appendix is typically surgical resection. This patient has a positive margin and also confirmed peritoneal disease. Low-grade adenocarcinoma of the appendix with the peritoneal disease is treated with an exploratory laparotomy with complete cytoreduction and heated intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC) . The HIPEC portion of the procedure includes temporary closure of the abdomen and infusion of heated chemotherapy (typically mitomycin C) into the abdomen, during which the abdomen is shaken vigorously for 90 minutes to allow all tissues to be exposed to the chemotherapeutic agent. The chemotherapy is then evacuated, the abdomen is irrigated and inspected, any anastomoses are per-formed, and the abdomen is closed.

Highyeild:

Patients with PMP have treatment with a combination of CRS (cytoreductive surgery) and HIPEC (hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy). The surgery can take over 10 hours and may involve various procedures to completely remove the tumor. Appropriate patient selection is crucial, and preoperative evaluation, including nutritional assessment, is essential. Following a complete cytoreduction, 5- and 10-year survival rates of 87% and 70%, respectively, can be achieved.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Exploratory laparotomy with peritonectomy is not the management of adenocarcinoma of the appendix. Management is Exploratory laparotomy, right hemicolectomy, complete cytoreduction, and intraperitoneal chemotherapy. Option: C. Intermediate- and high-grade tumors with the peritoneal disease are typically treated with systemic chemotherapy first and then reevaluated for cytoreduction and HIPEC. Option: D. Abdominal radiation is not given in the adenocarcinoma of Appendix. Note: Most common malignant appendicular tumour: Mucinous adenocarcinoma.

Extraedge:

Systemic chemotherapy may be considered for patients with high-grade or invasive unresectable disease or in the adjuvant setting following CRS/HIPEC. Chemotherapy is not typically considered for patients with low-grade pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP). Follow-up should include at least an annual clinical evaluation, monitoring of tumor markers, and CT scan for at least 10 years due to the possibility of late recurrence. The largest reported series of CRS/HIPEC comes from the UK, where a complete cytoreduction was achieved in 75% of patients.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents with right lower quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting. She undergoes an uncomplicated laparoscopic appendectomy. Postoperatively, the pathology reveals a 1cm well-differentiated (low-grade) mucinous adenocarcinoma with lymphatic invasion. Staging workup, including colonoscopy and computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis, is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in her management?

options.label: B
options.text: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by right hemicolectomy

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Appendectomy alone Appendiceal adenocarcinoma is a rare neoplasm accounting for less than 5% of GI tumors. Patients with well-differentiated adenocarcinoma only require a margin-negative appendectomy. Those with moderately or poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma require a formal right hemicolectomy . This is because lymph node metastases do not dictate the survival of those with well-differentiated adenocarcinoma but rather by peritoneal disease (of which this patient has none). Appendiceal cancer often affects older patients, which may present with symptoms mimicking those of acute appendicitis.

Highyeild:

Appendiceal Adenocarcinoma is a rare finding (<1%) in appendix removal surgery. Often found incidentally with longer symptom duration in older patients. Most common cell type is Mucinous adenocarcinoma. Mucinous adenocarcinoma has a better prognosis after resection, with a 5-year survival rate of nearly 50%. Recommended treatment is a right hemicolectomy.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A, B & D. Tumours less than 2cm need appendectomy only and not other extensive surgeries which have more complications and morbidity.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman who is 16 weeks pregnant has new onset of nausea, vomiting, and right-sided abdominal pain. Her body temperature is 37.5 oC. The pain has become worse over the past 6 hours. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Appendicitis Appendicitis complicates approximately 1 in 1700 pregnancies at an incidence comparable with that in nonpregnant women matched for age. It is the most prevalent extrauterine indication for laparotomy in pregnancy. The duration of gestation does not influence the severity of the disease, but the diagnosis does become more difficult as the pregnancy progresses. Pregnancy should not delay surgery if appendicitis is suspected; appendiceal perforation greatly increases the chance of premature labor and fetal mortality. Laparoscopic appendectomy can be performed safely during pregnancy in most cases. After appendicitis, biliary tract disease (biliary colic, cholecystitis) is the second most common non-obstetric surgical disease of the abdomen during pregnancy. Pancreatitis and intestinal obstruction are all less common general surgical conditions encountered during pregnancy. Appendicitis is the most common extrauterine abdominal emergency in pregnancy.

Highyeild:

Appendicitis is the most common non-obstetric surgical disease in pregnant women. The risk of appendicitis during pregnancy is similar to non-pregnant women of the same age, with an incidence of 1 in 2000 pregnancies. It can occur in any trimester but is slightly more frequent during the second trimester. Perforation is more common in the third trimester and can lead to fetal mortality rates of up to 35-50%. Diagnosis can be difficult due to common pregnancy symptoms and varying locations of tenderness with gestation.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B, C & D. In this case, Cholecystitis, and Pancreatitis Intestinal obstruction is less likely.

Extraedge:

Ultrasound can help diagnose and locate an inflamed appendix. Early appendectomy is the appropriate treatment for suspected appendicitis at any stage of pregnancy. Laparoscopic appendectomy is safe.

questions.correct_answer: A. The appendicular artery arises from the right colic artery
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The appendicular artery arises from the right colic artery The appendicular artery arises from the lower branch of the ileocolic artery and enters the mesoappendix {lies in the mesoappendix except at apex }behind the terminal ileum lying in its free border. The appendicular artery is an end artery, so when it is thrombosed in acute appendicitis, gangrene and perforation are inevitable. Perforation is most common at apex Option B C D: All other statements are correct.

Highyeild:

Appendix, ileum, and ascending colon originate from the midgut The appendiceal artery, a branch of the ileocolic artery supply the appendix The length of the appendix ranges from 2 to 20 cm with an average length of 9 cm in adults The base of the appendix is situated at the point where the taeniae meet on the inferior side of the cecum Retrocecal is the most common location for the appendix, while post-ileal is the least common.

Extraedge:

Accessory appendicular artery : Artery of Seshachalam- a branch of the posterior caecal artery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a factor that increases the chances of peritonitis and systemic sepsis in case of appendicitis.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Obesity The obese patient endowed with ample greater omentum will be protected from perforation and its sinister effects. Once there is an inflamed appendix, the greater omentum will help to localise the infection by enveloping the inflamed appendix preventing perforation and its ill effects.

Highyeild:

Conditions where perforation can occur: Infants, children : omentum is not fully developed. Pregnancy Adhesions Immunocompromised Elderly : vessels of omentum are atherosclerosed.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A, B & C. Are all conditions where perforation can occur.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of lower abdominal pain for the past 10 hours. The pain has progressively worsened and was accompanied by occasional episodes of diarrhea. She has vomited twice. Her mother has Crohn's disease. Her temperature is 38.1°C, the pulse is 95/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft, and there is mild tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant without rebound or guarding. Bowel sounds are normal. Her haemoglobin concentration is 13.0 g/dL, leukocyte count is 12,800/mm3, and platelet count is 345,000/mm3. The urine dipstick is negative for nitrites and leukocyte esterase. Urinalysis shows 3 WBC/hpf and no RBCs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ultrasound of the abdomen This patient has worsening right lower quadrant tenderness together with low grade fever and elevated WBC . Based on these features, one possible diagnosis is acute appendicitis. An abdomen ultrasound is the preferred initial imaging modality for diagnosing appendicitis in children or during pregnancy. An abdominal ultrasound is readily available, cost-effective, and does not expose the patient to radiation. Acute appendicitis is usually a clinical diagnosis, and imaging is not needed if the patient presents with typical clinical features (e.g., migrating abdominal pain, RLQ tenderness, rebound pain, fever, leukocytosis). Given this patient's family history of Crohn's disease (which makes inflammatory bowel disease a possible differential diagnosis), nonclassic presentation, and inconclusive clinical examination, abdominal ultrasound is indicated for further diagnosis. IOC for dd of appendicitis :: adults : CECT In children : USG . Finding on USG: Non-compressible elongated tubular structure with diameter>6mm and blind ending. Free fluid can also be present.

Highyeild:

It is important to note that while an abdominal ultrasound is the preferred initial imaging modality for diagnosing appendicitis in children or during pregnancy, it may not always be definitive in diagnosing the condition. In adults, a computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast (CECT) is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating suspected appendicitis. In children, an ultrasound can show a non-compressible, elongated tubular structure with a diameter greater than 6 mm and a blind-ending, which can suggest appendicitis. The presence of free fluid in the abdomen can also be an indicator of inflammation. However, it is important to note that a negative ultrasound does not completely rule out appendicitis, and clinical judgment should be used in conjunction with imaging findings for a definitive diagnosis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. A colonoscopy would be indicated to confirm a suspected diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) . This patient's right lower quadrant tenderness and history of diarrhoea are consistent with IBD, and her family history of Crohn's disease puts her at increased risk for this condition. However, the absence of abdominal cramps or bloody diarrhea makes this diagnosis less likely. Less invasive measures would be indicated before performing a colonoscopy. Option: C. A CT scan has a high sensitivity for diagnosing appendicitis and is the imaging modality of choice in adults . However, when radiation exposure should be avoided, e.g., in children or during pregnancy, a different imaging modality is preferred. A CT scan of the abdomen would be indicated to confirm or exclude appendicitis if the initial diagnostic studies are inconclusive. Option: D. An abdominal X-ray provides useful information for diagnosing several conditions, such as bowel obstruction, intussusception, and inflammatory bowel disease. Still, it is not the most appropriate next step because it has very low sensitivity for diagnosing acute appendicitis. In addition, it would expose the child to unnecessary radiation.

questions.text: The incision shown in image is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Grid iron incision Gridiron incision for appendicitis, at right angles to a line joining the anterior superior iliac spine and umbilicus, centred on McBurney’s point. It is a muscle-splitting incision.

Highyeild:

Open appendectomy done under general anaesthesia, but regional anaesthesia possible Incision made on McBurney's point - oblique/transverse or lower midline laparotomy for perforated appendicitis with phlegmon Muscle-splitting approach for well-paralyzed patients Trendelenburg's position with the left side down positioning of bed Mesentery ligation done early for better exposure If appendix base viable, ligation acceptable (Z-stitch, purse string, or mucosa fulguration) Fowler extension used for unexpected bleeding or appendiceal artery retraction Skin closure usually layered, but delayed primary or secondary intention closure considered for significant abscess or contamination No significant difference in surgical site infection rates between primary and delayed primary closure Placement of surgical drains not proven beneficial in clinical trials for complicated or uncomplicated appendicitis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Transverse or skin crease (Lanz) incision for appendicitis, 2 cm below the umbilicus, centred on the mid-clavicular–mid-inguinal line. Option: C. The Kocher’s incision is a subcostal incision on the right side of the abdomen used to expose the gallbladder and biliary tree. Option: D. Pfannenstiel-Kerr incision or pubic incision is an abdominal surgical incision that allows access to the abdomen. It is used for gynecologic and orthopaedics.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common position of vermiform appendix?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Retrocaecal Most common position: Retrocaecal 2 nd most common position: pelvic Least common position / most difficult to diagnose: post ileal The various positions of the appendix

Highyeild:

Retrocaecal Rigidity is usually absent, and even very deep pressure may not cause tenderness due to the caecum being distended with gas, which prevents the hand pressure from reaching the inflamed structure. However, deep tenderness is usually very present in the loin, and rigidity of the quadratus lumborum may be very evident. Psoas spasm, which is caused by the inflamed appendix coming into contact with that muscle, may be sufficient to cause hip joint flexion. When the degree of psoas spasm is insufficient to cause hip flexion, hyperextension of the hip joint may induce abdominal pain.

Extraedge:

In the case of the Postileal, the inflamed appendix lies behind the terminal ileum, causing the greatest difficulty in diagnosis because the pain may not shift, and diarrhea is often a feature, along with marked retching. Tenderness, if present, is ill-defined, although it may be present immediately to the right of the umbilicus.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female patient comes to OPD with a history of pain in the abdomen for the last 12 hours. The pain was at first periumbilical in location but became localised to the right iliac fossa after that. On examination, deep palpation of the left iliac fossa cause pain in the right iliac fossa . What is this sign known as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rovsing sign Rovsing’s sign is a pain in the right iliac fossa elicited on deep palpation of the left iliac fossa. Rovsing’s original description was to distend the caecum by pushing the bowel contents (gas) in an anti-peristaltic manoeuvre toward the ileocaecal valve, increasing pressure around the appendix. Others believe the pain in the right iliac fossa is a mere reflection of local peritoneal irritation.

Highyeild:

Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa may elicit Rovsing's sign, causing pain in the right iliac fossa. Occasionally, an inflamed appendix may lie on the psoas muscle, resulting in the patient lying with the right hip flexed for pain relief (the psoas sign). Pointing sign: the patient is asked to identify the location of their pain, which can help localise the site of inflammation. Spasm of the obturator internus muscle may be demonstrated when the hip is flexed and internally rotated. The obturator test or Zachary Cope sign may cause pain in the hypogastrium if the inflamed appendix is in contact with the obturator internus muscle. Cutaneous hyperesthesia may be present in the right iliac fossa, but it is rarely useful in diagnosing appendicitis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: C. ‘Pointing sign’ is merely asking the patient to point with one finger where the pain began and where it settled. When an inflamed appendix lies against the psoas muscle, the patient finds that the pain decreases on flexing the hip – the ‘psoas sign’. questions.text: A 4-year-old child is suspected of having acute appendicitis. In children, the following could be confused with acute appendicitis except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Urinary tract infection In children UTI is not commonly confused with acute appendicitis. UTI is a rare cause of acute abdominal pain; urinary symptoms, vomiting and fever are common features. Urinalysis and microscopy are helpful, although sterile pyuria might be present in acute appendicitis.

Highyeild:

Differential diagnosis of acute appendicitis in children: Acute gastroenteritis and mesenteric lymphadenitis can be mistaken for acute appendicitis. 's diverticulitis can be difficult to distinguish from acute appendicitis. Intussusception is more common in children under 2 and should be differentiated from appendicitis. Henoch-Schönlein purpura can cause severe abdominal pain and a distinctive ecchymotic rash. Lobar pneumonia and pleurisy can mimic appendicitis, but tenderness is minimal, and chest examination may reveal a pleural friction rub or altered breath sounds. A chest radiograph can confirm the diagnosis of pneumonia or pleurisy.

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . In acute gastroenteritis, abdominal pain, diarrhoea and vomiting usually start simultaneously, and rebound is uncommon. Option: B. Henoch-Schonlein purpura often starts with a sore throat and is associated with ecchymosis of the limbs and buttocks.

questions.text: In a 26 years old male, which of the following condition is not a differential diagnosis of acute appendicitis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mesenteric cyst Mesenteric cyst a lump should be palpable in the umbilical region with typical mobility not in right iliac region.

Highyeild:

Differential diagnosis of acute appendicitis in adults: Terminal ileitis can mimic acute appendicitis and is characterized by a doughy mass of inflamed ileum and a history of abdominal cramping, weight loss, and diarrhea. Urinary colic presents with different pain characteristics than appendicitis and can be diagnosed with urinalysis and imaging. Right-sided acute pyelonephritis may cause diagnostic difficulty and is characterised by fever, loin tenderness, and pyuria. Perforated peptic ulcer and appendicitis both present with right iliac fossa tenderness and rigidity, but the pain in peptic ulcer typically starts in the epigastrium. Testicular torsion can present with referred pain to the right iliac fossa, making it important to examine the scrotum in young males. Acute pancreatitis should be considered in the differential diagnosis of all adults suspected of having acute appendicitis and can be excluded by measuring serum or urinary amylase levels. Midcycle bleeding from a follicular cyst can cause lower abdominal and pelvic pain known as mittelschmerz. Torsion or haemorrhage of an ovarian cyst can present a challenging differential diagnosis requiring pelvic ultrasound and gynaecological evaluation.

Random:

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a complaint of abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting for 12 hours. Her temperature is 38.7°C. Physical examination shows severe right lower quadrant tenderness with rebound tenderness; bowel sounds are decreased. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis with left shift. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute appendicitis ALVARADO SCORING SYSTEM: SYMPTOMS: Migratory RIF pain -1 Anorexia -1 Nausea and vomiting -1 SIGNS: Tenderness (RIF)-2 Rebound tenderness-1 Elevated temperature- 1 LABORATORY: Leucocytosis-2 Shift to left- 1 Total- 10 SCORE CHANCES OF APPENDICITIS <5 UNLIKELY 5-6 POSSIBLE 7-8 LIKELY 9-10 HIGH LIKELY The patient presents with typical findings of diffuse abdominal pain which then localizes to right iliac fossa. Patient also has leukocytosis.

Highyeild:

To aid in diagnosis of acute appendicitis the Alvarado score being the most commonly used. A score of 7 or higher is highly indicative of acute appendicitis . In cases where the score is equivocal (5 or 6) , abdominal ultrasonography or contrast-enhanced CT examination can be helpful in reducing the rate of negative appendectomies.

Random:

Solution:

Although appendicitis pain classically localises to the right lower quadrant ( McBurney point ), in pregnant patients, the gravid uterus can displace the appendix towards the right upper quadrant. Sterile pyuria is a common finding in appendicitis and can occur if part of the urinary tract (usually the ureters) is within proximity of the inflamed appendix. McBurney's point is a landmark used in the diagnosis of appendicitis. It is located in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, approximately one third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) to the umbilicus. When there is inflammation of the appendix, McBurney's point may become tender to palpation. This tenderness is a key finding in the diagnosis of appendicitis, along with other symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for abdominal pain. She reports a vague loss of appetite for the past day and has had progressively severe abdominal pain, initially at her umbilicus, but now localized to her right lower quadrant. The pain is crampy. She has not moved her bowels or vomited. She reports that she is otherwise healthy and has had no sick contact. Exam is notable for a temperature of 100.7°F and heart rate of 105 bpm, but otherwise, vital signs are normal. Her abdomen is tender in the right lower quadrant, and pelvic examination is normal. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following imaging modalities is most likely to confirm her diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CECT IOC in case of appendicitis in adults is CECT and in children IOC is USG abdomen . The patient presents with typical findings for acute appendicitis with anorexia, progressing to vague periumbilical pain, followed by localization to the right lower quadrant. Low-grade fever and leukocytosis are frequently present. Although acute appendicitis is primarily a clinical diagnosis, imaging modalities are frequently employed because the symptoms are not always classic. Ultrasound may demonstrate an enlarged appendix with a thick wall but is most useful to rule out ovarian pathology, tubo-ovarian abscess, or ectopic pregnancy. CECT are superior to ultrasound or plain radiograph in the diagnosis of acute appendicitis with sensitivity of 0.94 and specificity of 0.95. Findings often include a thickened appendix with periappendiceal stranding and often the presence of a fecalith . Free air is uncommon, even in the case of a perforated appendix. Nonvisualization of the appendix on CT is associated with surgical findings of a normal appendix 98% of the time.

Highyeild:

Ultrasound has a very good sensitivity of 85% and a very high specificity of over 90% for diagnosing acute appendicitis in patients with abdominal pain. Characteristic findings on ultrasound include a very enlarged appendix with a diameter of ≥ 7 mm, a thick-walled, noncompressible luminal structure seen in cross-section (target lesion), or the presence of an appendicolith. Ultrasound is commonly used in children and pregnant patients with equivocal clinical findings suggestive of acute appendicitis. A calcified appendicolith is visible in only 10–15% of patients with acute appendicitis on plain X-ray. Failure of the appendix to fill during a barium enema has been associated with appendicitis, although this finding is not very sensitive or specific as up to 20% of normal appendices do not fill.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Colonoscopy has no role in the diagnosis of acute appendicitis Option: C & D. The effectiveness of ultrasonography as a tool to diagnose appendicitis is highly operator dependent.

Extraedge:

CT scan is a diagnostic tool with a high sensitivity (90%) and specificity (80-90%) for acute appendicitis in patients presenting with abdominal pain. CT scan can identify a distended appendix of more than 7 mm in diameter with a thickened and enhanced circumferential wall, giving the appearance of a halo or target, which are classic findings for acute appendicitis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl was diagnosed with acute appendicitis. Which of the following is the least likely position of this organ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Post ileal Least common is postileal In case of Appendicitis , it is most difficult to diagnose in Post Ileal Appendix

Highyeild:

Retrocaecal position of appendix Rigidity is usually absent, and even intense pressure may not cause tenderness due to the caecum being distended with gas, which prevents the hand pressure from reaching the inflamed structure. However, deep tenderness is usually very present in the loin, and rigidity of the quadratus lumborum may be very evident. Psoas spasm, which is caused by the inflamed appendix coming into contact with that muscle, may be sufficient to cause hip joint flexion. When the degree of psoas spasm is insufficient to cause hip flexion, hyperextension of the hip joint may induce abdominal pain.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Most common position is retrocaecal Option: C. 2 ND most common site: pelvic Option: D. Paracaecal : 2% likely position

Extraedge:

In the case of post ileal, the inflamed appendix lies behind the terminal ileum, causing the greatest difficulty in diagnosis because the pain may not shift, and diarrhea is often a feature, along with marked retching. Tenderness, if present, is ill-defined, although it may be present immediately to the right of the umbilicus.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female is diagnosed with an appendicular mass. Management in this case, should be?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Conservative If an appendix mass is present and the patient's condition is satisfactory, the standard treatment is the conservative Ochsner–Sherren regime . This strategy is based on the premise that the inflammatory process is already localised and that inadvertent surgery is difficult and may be dangerous. It may be impossible to find the appendix and occasionally, a faecal fistula may form.

Highyeild:

In cases where an appendix mass is present, and the patient is stable , the recommended treatment approach is the conservative Ochsner-Sherren regimen . This method assumes that the inflammation is localised . Surgical intervention can be risky and challenging, potentially resulting in complications such as fecal fistulas or the inability to locate the appendix. Therefore, a non-operative approach should be pursued, but the medical team should be prepared to perform surgery promptly if the patient's condition deteriorates. To confirm the diagnosis, a CECT abdomen should be conducted, and the patient should receive antibiotics such as Metronidazole plus a 3rd generation of cephalosporin or a single dose of ertapenem In the event of an abscess , radiological drainage is necessary. The patient's temperature and pulse rate should be monitored every four hours, and fluid balance should be maintained. If clinical deterioration or evidence of peritonitis occurs, early laparotomy is recommended. Clinical improvement typically occurs within 24-48 hours. Failure of the mass to resolve may suggest the presence of Crohn's disease or carcinoma.

For these reasons, it is wise to observe a non-operative programme but to be prepared to operate should clinical deterioration occur. questions.text: A 19-year-old girl comes with periumbilical pain, which was later restricted to the right iliac fossa. She was diagnosed with acute appendicitis. An appendicectomy was done. Which of the following statement is false regarding complications of this surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: Wound infection is the least common post-operative complication

options.label: B
options.text: Few patients can develop intra-abdominal abscess

options.label: C
options.text: The most common late complication is adhesive intestinal obstruction

options.label: D
options.text: Wound infection usually presents with pain and erythema of the wound on the fourth or fifth postoperative day

questions.correct_answer: A. Wound infection is the least common post-operative complication
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Wound infection is the least common post-operative complication Wound infection is the most common postoperative complication, occurring in 5–10% of all patients. This usually presents with pain and erythema of the wound on the fourth or fifth postoperative day, often soon after hospital discharge. Treatment is by wound drainage and antibiotics when required.

Highyeild:

Complications of Appendectomy The most common postoperative complication is wound infection, which affects 5-10% of all patients. Intra-abdominal abscess is another possible complication. Ileus, a condition in which the intestines do not move properly, can also occur. Respiratory complications are rare but can happen. Venous thrombosis and embolism, a blood clot in the veins, is a potential risk. Portal pyaemia, also known as pylephlebitis, is another rare complication. Adhesive intestinal obstruction is the most common late complication of appendectomy. During surgery, a single band adhesion is often the culprit.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B C & D. All other statements are correct.
